title: Can electricity transfer through the air and if yes, then how? - Quora

response.answer_text: Only in extreme forms such as lightning. The reason is simply that electricity requires a conductor to travel, and air normally isn’t one. But we don’t need electricity itself to travel through the air. We just need a form of energy that will, and that we can readily convert electricity to and from. In the same way that we don’t need to store electricity in a rechargeable battery, but rather we can store chemical energy in a form that we can readily convert electricity to and from. Energy travelling through the air is electromagnetic energy. Like light or radio or X-Rays or magnetism. Well, to be comprehensive you could include some form of particle beam, but that’s hardly going to work for this case! The problem is that EM energy either tends to spread out and so becomes diluted very quickly with distance, like light from a light bulb, or if we focus it then it only goes in a single direction and becomes potentially dangerous to anything in its path, like a laser. So we can easily transmit energy over very short distances, such as by using magnetic fields as in existing wireless charging technology. But over longer distances it becomes all about tracking a beam of energy, and shutting this off when interrupted. Which results in technologies like this one: Wi-Charge.com. This example uses a beam of infra-red to transfer energy, using feedback from target devices to continuously direct the beam in the right direction and cut it off whenever something else interrupts the beam. Notice in particular that the marketing for this technology emphasises safety and FDA approval, the manufacturers being wary of the dangers. To achieve this they’ve had to limit the power, so the best case is 5W delivered over 5 metres. Even then this is a powerful beam. If we say that 5W is delivered to an area of 1 sq cm on the receiver, then this concentration is around a 100 times that of the Sun’s infrared energy when the Sun is overhead. At the same time this represents a slow charge in today’s terms, and effectively limited to nearly overhead transmission. In fact this comparison ignores receiver efficiency. If the receiver is only 20% efficient then we’re talking about 500 times Sun equivalent, or alternatively just 1 W charging. It turns out that the latter is roughly in line with best case in published reviews. 1W charging is roughly a maintenance charge for a modern phone - it will just about maintain existing charge levels when the phone is idle. Also of course you need a plug in receiver for your phone. So as with magnetic wireless charging such as Qi, the idea of overhead charging is only likely to succeed if the manufacturers can persuade mobile phone manufacturers to incorporate receivers built in to their phones. All in all this really doesn’t look like a practical solution, and it’s very difficult to see how this could be improved significantly without unacceptable safety risk.

Well, there is electricity and there is electrical energy.   Electricity can indeed be transferred through the air - but standard temperature and pressure air has very high resistance to the flow of electric current.  This is a good thing and makes walking under high voltage power lines more convenient. Voltage is electrical pressure somewhat analogous to water pressure.  Once a sufficiently high voltage (approximately some 30,000 volts across an air gap of 1cm) has started electric current flowing through air, things get out of hand in a hurry as the air itself changes composition by ionizing. Ionized air has a very low resistance so electricity can flow in quantity; once an electric arc gets started it can be hard to extinguish. This is the spark you see when you unplug an appliance - as even the household 110 volts is enough to get the current flowing through air if the 'gap' starts small enough. Nature uses millions of volts for lightning and therefore has much more fun.  Same electricity, largely the same physics. Generally, passing energy through a non-conductor like air is best done by converting the electrical energy to something that the air does not impede.  To do this electricity is generally first converted into either of two forms of energy: photons (light) and magnetic fields. Converting electric energy to light and sending that light through the air to be re-converted to electricity is done by devices as simple as your TV remote control.  Batteries power the infrared LED and at the TV end photo-receptors convert received infrared photons into an electric current. Converting electric energy to magnetic fields and recovering that energy is the technology behind 'wireless chargers' now coming to your local handheld device.

For current to flow, there must be free electrons in the medium through which electricity is to pass. Metals have a kernel of free electrons in their structure which enables the flow of current. A material which is non-conductor of electricity will not be having free electrons to conduct the electricity. Air is a non-conductor of electricity because it does not have free electrons to carry the current. But when there is high voltage, as in case of lightening, the molecules of air get ionized and electrons are available to flow to make the current and conduct electricity through air. This is called “dielectric breakdown” of air. When the molecules of air get ionized, sound and light is released which we can see during lightening. So, coming to your question, yes, we can conduct electricity through air if we apply sufficiently high voltage to cause the air to ionize. But we cannot conduct electricity through vacuum where there are no molecules to provide the electrons.

yes it do transfer through air but its dielectric constant is very high...for practical purposes it can't be used as conducting medium and regarded as insulating medium.One example of air as conducting medium is lightning strike through clouds.For very short distances  most common form of wireless power transmission is carried out using direct induction followed by resonant magnetic induction. Other methods under consideration are electromagnetic radiation in the form of microwaves or lasers and electrical conduction through natural media. In these all methods energy is transferred in to some other form like magnetic or radiation then it travels through air,received  at other end and transferred back to electrical energy.

Sort of. Lightning is preceeded by a stage where the air is conducting charged ions that might keep conducting and reducing the charge on the clouds until it has leaked away. This is what lightning rods are designed to do. If the charge on the cloud is too high or the cloud too close to the ground the current is greater, causing the resistance of the air to break down and conduct more readily, the resulting flash is lightning. Deliberate conduction other than across small gaps is highly undesirable as the air is unpredictable and people, animals and objects in the vicinity would be likely to be hit.

Yes it can pass… You will be scratching your head, but yeah it's true. If some one knows about electrostatics and dielectrics... He must have heard about the term DIELECTRIC BREADOWN/BREAKDOWN VOLTAGE…which simply means that at certain higher potential/voltage difference insulators too behave as conductors... Have you ever noticed when there is some lightning happens... Its drops down from sky which is at higher potential to the earth/ground which is at lower potential...it goes from sky to ground through AIR, which some might say is insulator…see the irony... INSULATORS TOO CONDUCT ELECTRICITY... Hope you like the answer.... Please upvote and share... :)

Yes, it can. Electrical current flowing through air is called an arc. All sorts of arc welders do this as a part of the way they work. Arcing is a real problem with high voltage switching. A Tesla coil does it at high frequency and voltage. For that matter, a standard internal combustion engine arcs at the spark plug. The “Kettering” ignition uses it. Even had static electricity from the carpet? That can do it too. For that matter, even nature does it on a big scale - Lightning…

actually at anytime ,electricity passes through the air when there is even a small voltage…but the magnitude of the current is too small to consider it as the electricity flow…it may be in micro or nano amperes in magnitude so we doesn't consider it as a electricity. Air is a material which has very high resistance.its dielectric strength is 30 kv/cm on standard conditions.it varies according to temperature,pressure and moisture content in the air.so if we are able to apply a potential of 30 kv for a length of 1 cm,the air will conduct….

This is a wonderful question to raise. While I can hardly claim to know more than you regarding this, I believe Nikola Tesla, the pioneer of electrical energy, had thought of this very model, though he was unable to implement it. You cannot transmit electricity per se, but you can transmit energy - indeed, we do it all the time! Think of radios and modern telecommunication sets: the signals are all transmitted through air as electromagnetic energy!

Yes, ofcourse. Because we already transmit electromagnetic signals wirelessly, so a wireless power transmission system would ideally be an identical thing except for the fact that in case of the later, the EM wave would be expected to have higher power and the process would be expected to be much more power efficient. Currently we have some cell phone models charging wirelessly. Wireless power transfer

But that requires very high voltage (Energy) that could turn air into Plasma which then could conduct the electricity. Its dangerous and but it is possible. Ever heard of Tesla coils, they do it.

Actually current can be made to flow in any insulator after the insulator goes into the state of dielectric breakdown(D.B.). Air being an insulator,if an electric field of the order of ~10^4 V/m or more is applied between any two points starts conducting current. Lightning is a perfect example of D.B.

Yes it can travel through air and lighting is an example, however air is a very bad conductor of electricity and therefore it requires a huge amount of energy to pass electricity through it. The potential difference across a lightning bolt can go upto 30 thousand volts. So it can not be an efficient method for electric transmission
Electricity? Yes, lightning is a great example. Typical air acts like an insulator, but that just means you have to push harder (higher voltage) to get flowing.
Electricity can indeed be transferred through the air but standard temperature and pressure air has very high resistance to the flow of electric current.
NO air has infinite resistance But under certain circumstances like in the Tesla tower which stimulates lightning air can pass through it to reach the concentration of opposite charge
When the Atmospheric gas pressure increases it starts to conduct electricity but not in a controlled manner ... We don't feel shock in air because our atmospheric pressure is 1 atm

Yes electricity flow in air… That is what you see during a thunderstorm… You see a lot of lightnings streaking in the sky… That is a very high voltage of electricity being discharge between the clouds and the ground passing through the air…as air becomes more conductive during a storm..
Yes. It's called ionization of gases. The ionized gas is called plasma. I'm sure that explains the lightning as well.

Air under a very low temperature and pressure conducts electricity. This is the fact behind the thunder reaches the ground through air. Though, a very high voltage is required to overcome the resistance of air
